The climax leaves you in a bitter sweet taste and you can't escape from the questions it raises to you. Movie is slow paced, takes its sweet time before action starts. It's the Jack Nicholson's finest acting show that keeps you glued to the screen. Lousie Fletcher plays the Jack's counterpart of hard faced rule book following nurse quite competently. All other supporting characters are also well developed and play their part to the perfection. It's not the storytelling or drama that leaves you spell binded but it is the emotional depth and the soulful characters that leave the lasting impression on you. Not to be missed for whom who like the cinema to be unconventional.

title: Amazing
review: It's taken me some time, but I've finally seen One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. An amazing film it is, with the entire cast doing incredibly strong work. I'm not going to do a long review, but there's such majestic beauty in this that amounts to a larger picture. The ending is amazing, and worthy of awe-inspiring chills at the same time. Nicholson is fantastic in the lead role, the best I've ever seen him and if anything now I'm more interested in seeking out the rest of his extensive filmography and acclaimed performances I haven't seen. Then there's the infamous Nurse Ratched, but I didn't get what I expected. She's the worst kind of villain, but also the most interesting kind, one where her actions aren't exactly what makes you truly despise her but the way she goes about her manners. Fletcher is amazing and is probably one of my all-time favorite supporting female performances now (let's be honest here. Just like Hopkins in The Silence of the Lambs, category fraud at its worst). Brad Douriff also stands out from the supporting cast. Truly fantastic.

title: The Good Stuff Is So Good You Can Overlook The Flaws
review:
CUCKOO'S NEST is one of only three pictures in Hollywood history to win The Big Four at Oscar Time: Picture, Actor, Actress, and Director (the other two are 1934's IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT and 1991's THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS). And despite some serious flaws I have to admit it deserved every single one of those awards, because the things this movie does well it does so amazingly well that the story carries you along and you don't even think about the flaws until much later.

I won't bother to lay out any plot details; even people who haven't seen it know the basic premise: the film is basically a power struggle between R P McMurphy (Jack Nicholson), a con artist who fakes crazy to get better accommodations (the State Mental Hospital instead of the County Jail), and Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher), a cold, manipulative, and power-hungry woman who treats the men in her care more like pieces on a chessboard than actual human beings. In brief, McMurphy and Ratched square off into one of the most memorable clashes of conflicting wills ever put on film. Those are the basics, and I'll stop there: if you don't know the rest, see the movie; it's worth it.

I also highly recommend reading the novel for comparison, because the book's author, Ken Kesey, is said to have hated the film because in his view it shifted the focus of the story from Chief Bromden (Will Sampson), who narrates the book as a sort of internal monologue and through whose eyes the action of the book plays out, to McMurphy.

I have a hard time understanding Kesey's negative reaction, because McMurphy is still the central character in the book despite the narrative voice of Bromden, and to have kept that narrative voice in the film would have been impossible. For one thing, Bromden spends half the story pretending to be a deaf-mute, fooling everyone including Ratched. Forman would have had to let the audience into the secret from the beginning; instead we discover it along with the entire cast. The only other things missing are Bromden's hallucinations, which would have been impossible to film even as recently as 1975; it could be done with CGI in today's technology, but I don't know as it would necessarily be an improvement. The only other difference I noted was that the fishing trip in the movie was the penultimate act of rebellion; in the novel the men have full permission from the doctor, who even goes with them. A bit hard to make the case for rebellion, though Nurse is, of course, far from happy about it.

Now for the flaws. To my mind, both the novel and the film have one HUGE flaw: the portrayal of women. Ken Kesey appears to have been heterosexual by all accounts, but watching the film (and especially reading the novel), it is easy to get the impression that he really hated women on some level. All the women in both book and movie fall into a variant on Freud's "madonna/whore" complex. The "madonnas" in this case are all emasculating ball-busters; be they nurses or wives, these ladies all "wear the pants" in whatever situation they are in. The whores are, well, whores: two prostitutes who are really the only pleasant female characters in this thing.

The other major flaw is that there is very little actual mental illness in this film. Bromden's hallucinations didn't make it to the screen, and the others, while somewhat neurotic, are far from sick enough to be hospitalized. One of them, Sefelt (William Duell), is an epileptic, hardly a reason to be inpatient. Their problems all seem to relate to the women in their lives, and Ratched has every one of them completely cowed. McMurphy's effect on them suggests that the culture of Momism has neutered these men and that the best therapy for them is simply to "act like guys." This misogyny is less pointed in the film than it is in the novel, but it's there nonetheless.

Still, these things are easy to miss in light of the film's staggering accomplishments. Jack Nicholson has never been one of my favorite actors, but the Oscars are full of occasions where the role and the actor were so perfectly matched that the actor owned it. Nicholson owned McMurphy; in fact to some extent he has been working with variations of the McMurphy persona ever since.

Louise Fletcher, an actress who up to that time had done mostly television, had to audition several times over the course of six months before finally getting the part of Nurse Ratched; director Milos Forman kept telling her she was not quite grasping the part yet kept calling her back to read, and she must have finally found the right notes, or Forman simply could not find anyone he thought was better. In the end it matters not at all: Fletcher's performance as the precise and icy Ratched is a memorable bit of acting, fully deserving of her Oscar, especially when you realize that the character as written is pretty one-note, which placed huge demands on her to make the woman, if not exactly sympathetic, at least interesting. And she goes beyond interesting: Ratched is fascinating in the way they say snakes can make their prey freeze and be unable to move just by nailing them with their eyes.

This film has an undeniable power, and even now it is easy to see why it is in the American Film Institute's Top 100 (#33, if that interests anyone). It entertains while making you think. The only thing is you might find yourself coming to some really unsettling conclusions.

title: Unfortunate Insanity
review:
I found this movie difficult to watch, not because of the subject matter, but because it initially seemed as unsure of its destination as I was. It is entirely understandable that a movie about a mental institution would provide an insight into the daily routine of the inhabitants which is most likely quite dull and, well, routine. It is also necessary to provide for character development, but too much monotony and introduction is just difficult to watch. This is not to say that any of the actors were negligent in their craft. Everyone was very believable in their respective roles, so much so that it took me a while to recognize Danny DeVito. Jack Nicholson was his usually boisterous and slightly insane self and Louise Fletcher was a superb Nurse Ratched. The technical aspects of the movie were sufficient and fluid, but did not draw attention to themselves with any particularly notable exhibition of flair.

The second half did pick up a bit and the ending misses making the movie more than just worth watching by only a tiny fraction. I suppose I just can't help but feel a bit unsure about whether or not anyone actually escaped and whether or not that is the movie's intent on how I should feel.

title: if you don't like this movie you are crazier than they are
review: i saw the last half of this movie years and years ago and didn't understand it... its a complex and compelling character driven drama that takes place for the most part in the plainly lit and shot angular world of a mental hospital... i was 8... nowadays i not only saw the film start to finish i could look at it as an aspiring film maker with a fresh appreciation for not only the powerful immortal characterizations portrayed but the brilliantly simple camera work. like i said the movie takes place in a hospital so the characters don't have far to run (the less disabled characters anyway some never move) instead the cameras job is simply to stay put and record the subtleties and nuances of each actors screen time... nothing more nothing less... the lighting is simple hospital lights daylight or dimly lit night... the technical aspects of the film are there to frame the acting not to dazzle or distract the audience... the acting is superb powerful and Oscar worthy... also worth mention is the fact i nearly died when i realized danny devito was in this movie... many actors i didn't realize were in this deliver some of the better characters notably christopher lloyd and brad douriff i wont say much of the story except that its a roller-coaster from start to finish and its worth watching a few times

title: Excellent, if slightly 'Theactrical'...
review:
Based on a novel by Ken Kesey, and later a play by Dale Wasserman, this film won 5 Oscars including; Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor and Best Actress. So it looks like it's a 'must see', which, to a large extent, it is. I did find, though, that as a translation of a novel/stage play to the big screen it did suffer from being just a little too, well, theatrical (for want of a better word). I don't want to detract from some truly excellent performances, but, as a whole, I did come away very slightly disappointed. As usual, my thoughts after this brief summary.

R.P. McMurphy has been transferred from a local prison to a mental hospital for observation. The authorities believe he is trying to feign mental illness to get out of his work detail and, to this end, they want a professional opinion. He is put into a ward under the watchful care of Nurse Ratched, a quite formidable, but caring, woman. The other 'inmates' have a variety of problems and demonstrate these in a variety of ways. McMurphy immediately tries to put his brand of democracy on his comrades in his first group discussion, but Nurse Ratched is having none of it. Thus begins a battle of wills that, at times is frustrating, uplifting, funny and even tragic. Life continues like this, and McMurphy even makes a big enough impact to be kept there and not be returned to prison. But when he discovers that he is not just there until the end of his sentence, but until they decide he's sane enough to leave, things take a turn. Now determined to leave for good, McMurphy hatches a plan to escape with at least one of his new friends. I'll leave it here so the Spoiler Police don't try to put me back in that institution.

As I've already hinted, tremendous performances from both the leading man, Jack Nicholson as R.P. McMurphy and the leading lady, Louise Fletcher as Nurse Ratched. Both were superb; Nicholson with his free-flowing, improvised style and Fletcher with her more measured approach. Also worthy of note were; Danny DeVito, who I hardly recognised, as Martini, Sydney Lassick as Charley Cheswick, Christopher Lloyd as Taber, Vincent Schiavelli as Fredrickson, Brad Dourif as Billy Bibbit, Mews Small as Candy and, not forgetting, Will Sampson as Chief Bromden.

I did find this film a little bit like watching a play at times, it did branch out occasionally, but the vast majority of the action takes place on the ward, which I did find slightly claustrophobic. It was very well made, with quite a few scenes, particularly those featuring Jack Nicholson, being improvised to some extent. I really enjoyed these scenes, as they were allowed to evolve I would really love to see some outtakes! Over all though, an interesting film that deserves all the accolades it's got over the years For me, a little bit too much like a play, but then I can only be honest about how I feel about it. Even so, highly recommended.

My Score: 9.1/10.

IMDb Score: 8.9/10 (based on 260,412 votes when this review was written).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 96/100 (based on 51 reviews counted when this review was written).

title: Don't watch this movie if you cry too damn easily.
review:
Wow, and I mean wow. This movie really got me deeply. It's one of those movies where you feel like the characters are ones you just want to love. Jack Nicholson was far beyond the boundaries of amazing with his performance. Randle Mcmurphy is one of the best characters of all time, and Jack Nicholson was perfect for the part.

Okay, so the movie takes place in a mental institute because Mcmurphy pretends to be crazy so he can go to a mental institute instead of going to jail. He doesn't realize that the institute is in fact worse than prison itself. However, he does make friends with patients of the institute. He soon makes friends with The Chief (Not that other guy from Halo), the only Indian throughout the whole movie. I don't want to spoil anything about the character but he is just as amazing as Mcmurphy in terms of character and likability.

I'll stop there in terms of the plot. Watch the movie to truly understand how gorgeous this movie really is. This movie could possibly make you cry, so get tissues just in case. Maybe this movie could help promote mental institutes being horrible Nazi-like places.

P.S. If you thought PIXAR movies could really get to you big time in terms of emotion, WATCH OUT, 'cause this nearly breaks the emotional barrier of PIXAR movies. It breaks your heart.

Gorgeous movie. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves good character development and grade A+++ script and A+++ tear-jerking.

title: Well-deserved Oscar film for 1975
review:
"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is truly one of Jack Nicholson's films yet to date. Nicholson gives a truly award-winning performance as convict R.P. McMurphy who fakes insanity to get out of a prison work program. At the start of the film, he is sent to the mental institute in Oregon. He starts to get to know some of the residents on the ward, and the staff including a no-nonsense nurse well played by Louise Fletcher who won an award for best actress. Brad Dourif gave an excellent performance as Billy Bibbit and Will Sampson was as equally impressive as the tall Native American resident, Chief. Christopher Lloyd and Danny DeVito should also be mentioned for their acting contributions for their respective roles as Taber and Martini, and this was before they would gain fame a couple of years later in the hit TV show, "Taxi". And of course, Scatman Crothers' performance as Turkel, the night orderly is definitely not to be missed.

McMurphy's character and attitude slowly begin to change in the institute when he realizes that most of the residents on the ward are there voluntarily. His breaking point is when he's about to escape from the hospital, he stays to let Billy have a night of passion with the former's floozy girlfriend, Candy, well played by Marya Smalls. And when he has his last chance at freedom, he blows it by running to Billy's side towards the end. The climatic scene at the end with Chief lifting up the sink off its foundation and ramming it thru the hospital window is truly inspiring.

title: " Be careful what you wish for, you just might get it "
review: There are times when a clever man in prison becomes so smart he's stupid. Case in point, This movie called " One Flew over the Cuckoo's nest " is based on a true story and directed by Milos Foreman. It's the story of a slippery convict who feigns being mentally unbalanced to avoid a prison work detail and in doing so, is transfered to an insane asylum. R.P. McMurphy (Jack Nickleson) is a scheming, conniving, smart-ass who believes he can forgo mandatory prison work by pretending to be 'crazy.' Unfortuntately there is a penalty to be paid when he encounters the dictator-like nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) who turns out to be a vindicate bitch, who sees through his scheme and his effort to take advantage of the slow witted patients under her authority. Patiently, she allows McMurphy to try and change the rules and established policies, but is assured her power and control will remain intact. The duel is engaged as they spar and struggle for dominance as each tries to secure the inmates' cooperation. Eventually, the controlled setting is disrupted by McMurphy's increasing antics, each drawing him into a direct confrontation with Ratched and the powers that be. The question remains? Who will end up controlling the place. The actors playing the inmate are incredible and memorable. Scatman Crothers, Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd, Brad Dourif, Mimi Sarkisian and Will Sampson. This is a true classic. ****

title: It deserves its rank as #8
review:
I love the psychological ride that I took watching this movie. I laughed, I cried and I could feel the anger for Nurse Ratched throughout the entire film. It is so hard to take her condescending attitude. It is so sad what they used to do to people in psyche wards! This film truly shows that. An astonishing masterpiece. I loved it. Every minute of it. I love how McmMurphy caused chaos, but in a good way. He brought them happiness.

Nurse Ratched resented how he could have more control over them, because they liked him and that was certainly intriguing to see. The ending is sad, truly sad, but life cannot be all full of happy endings. Not everyone has a happy ending. At least one cuckoo gets out. One of my favorite movies for sure.

title: Which one of you nuts has got any guts?
review:
"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", Czech filmmaker Milos Forman's second American film and, as of 2010, one of only three films to win the top 5 Oscars for Picture, Director, Actor, Actress and Screenplay (the others being "It Happened One Night" and "The Silence of the Lambs"), is a masterpiece of institutionalized melodrama, dark comedy, good vs. evil, man vs. the establishment.

R.P. McMurphy (Jack Nicholson in one of the all time great screen performances) is a 38 year-old troublemaker whose latest conviction is for the statutory rape of a 15 year-old girl - he claims she said she was 18. By playing mad, he is transferred from jail to a mental institution, where he believes things will be easier. However, Nurse Mildred Ratched (Louise Fletcher), always cold and impassive to sarcasm, will be a stone in his shoe - especially as McMurphy starts to ignite the other inmates's (Brad Dourif, Will Sampson, Christopher Lloyd, Vincent Schiavelli and Danny DeVito, among others) rebellion against Ratched's oppression.

Some will argue that the film portrays the inmates as caricatures (quite a few of them are there voluntarily) at the mercy of McMurphy's game, which might be true to some extent. Nonetheless, each character, from the fragile Billy (Dourif) to the quiet Chief (Sampson) is absolutely human and believable in their quirkiness, and Nicholson is the rebellious and charismatic anti-hero whose flaws seem to be minor when he becomes such a pal to these miserable, oppressed creatures. We hate Nurse Ratched so much because she represents all of those with enough to power to oppress those who are "smaller" - whether she actually believes what she does is for the better becomes almost irrelevant when we see the damage she is able to cause, and it's that paradox that makes it such a complex character and Louise Fletcher's performance, so effective. The scene where McMurphy finally confronts and almost strangles her is one of the greatest battles in film history; the very ending, where Chief realizes that choking McMurphy to death is the only way of setting him free, then getting away himself, is a moment of synthesis more poignant and disorienting than that from the touching crowd-pleaser "The Shawshank Redemption". McMurphy's rebellion changed a few lives somehow, freed Chief, "killed" Billy and ultimately himself. In the end, McMurphy lost to the establishment, but he still managed to plant his seed somewhere. And yes, if you look at it from the right, or more positive angle, after all these years, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" remains an inspirational story, rather than a cautionary tale. See also: its distant female cousin, James Mangold's underrated "Girl, Interrupted" (1999).

title: Memorable, horrifying, powerful.
review:
It's difficult to imagine many films aging as well as 1975's 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'. Though practices have changed and opinions differ drastically than they did when the original 1962 novel was released, this moving and powerful picture remains every bit as good as I'm sure it was more than thirty years ago. It touches brilliance and touches it often, and it's difficult to describe it as anything other than a masterpiece.

A beautiful, tragic, maddening masterpiece. A culturally profound and historically significant picture that asks what it truly means to be sane, or insane for that matter. And though it at times can be very funny and genuinely life-affirming, 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is often a difficult film to watch as its many characterizations are all strikingly human. Real people dealing with real problems, all built around a sharp and intelligent observation of how we deal with mental illness.

Jack Nicholson has delivered some mighty fine performances during his rich career, and he's sure to deliver some more. But it's his turn here as McMurphy that will surely go down as one of his best and most accomplished pieces of work. It is, like the film, flawless. As he not-so-eloquently (but the ends justify the means, right?) battles both himself and his fellow patients to fight oppression and free the individual from within, an unforgettable clash with Nurse Ratched crackles with tension, both real and psychological. Louise Fletcher turns in an absolutely mesmerizing performance here, bringing to life a truly disturbing character that's both upsetting and very thought-provoking.

'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' isn't a film made for the criminally insane, but for you and me. It's an electric story that remains a relevant and relatable piece of artwork. A comedy one minute and a heartbreaking tearjerker the next, few films have achieved a level of excellence as director Milos Forman has here. A remarkable achievement, and an ending that's both empowering and disheartening that will leave a lasting impression on any who have the extreme fortune of experiencing 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest', one of the greatest films ever made.

More reviews at rottentomatoes.com/vine/journal_view.php?journalid=219276&view=public

title: One Flew Over The Cuckoos nest
review:
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest was a product of Kesey's time, he used to work at a mental facility. Also, he used to take medicine and he experienced how to be in a mental facility. The story center of attention is on Randle McMurphy, where he transfered from a workfarm to a psychiatric hospital. The two main characters that stood out the most for me was Patrick McMurphy and chief Bromden. The psychiatric hospital is based in an all men asylum. A movie like this expresses how unsympathetic life can be in a mental hospital or other types o facilities.

Randle Patrick McMurphy is brought from a work farm to a mental facility to be examine of a mental illness that he can have. McMurphy is an all loving type of guy, and very charismatic. He was charge of child rape but never been convicted of. He decided to change the routines of the patients by watching the World Series on television, running the card table, playing basketball, and by organizing a fishing trip. He wanted for everyone to be treated as normal such as pleasing their needs. A major point of the movie was when he says that, he just is going to be for one hundred and sixty five days. It was not true because the nurse had to tell him when it was okay for him to leave the facility. At that point, he noticed that he should have stay at the workfarm. Also, when at the end he end up being like one of the rest because he is a near negative vegetative state to its most elderly patients.

Another character that impacted me was chief Bromden. In the beginning, he acts as a dumb deaf person but in the end he ends up being the most the most intelligent and loyal to a friend. The Chief Bromden is a Native American that has been there since World War II. He knows all the secrets of the mental institution since everyone thinks he cannot hear. He was a potent man of over six feet tall but he sees himself very small compared to McMurphy. McMurphy teaches him to believe in himself and to regain self respect. In the end, he helps McMurphy by killing so he wont have to suffer as being vegetative.

title: A great film about a fight for freedom
review:
This film is one of Hollywood's great films about an individual's fight to find freedom in an oppressive environment. Randall MacMurphy (Jack Nicholson 1975's Best Actor) is a prison convict judged to possibly be mentally ill and sent for evaluation to a mental hospital in 1960s Oregon. In the hospital he is under the "care" of Nurse Ratchett (Louis Fletcher in an Oscar-winning role) who is cold and unsympathetic to MacMurphy and all the other inmates. She desires order and obedience from the men in her charge. This immediately sets MacMurphy and Ratchett at odds as MacMurphy is not about to be anyone's lackey.

MacMurphy demonstrates his desire for freedom and individuality in many ways . He gets Ratchett to OK a vote to decide if the inmates will be able to alter their strict work schedule and watch the World Series. MacMurphy thinks he has won when all the cognizant inmates vote to watch the game. But Ratchett stifles Randall's bid when she insists on counting the catatonic members of "the group" as "No" votes so MacMurphy is frustrated in his effort.

MacMurphy desires to prove to his minders that he is mentally ill and should not be sent back to prison, so he escapes from the hospital with Cheswick, Taygor, Harding, Martinia and others and absconds with a charter boat so the men can go fishing. This effort surely puts Randal in hot water with hospital officials, but it accomplishes MacMurphy's goal of being kept in the mental hospital. What he does not know and no one told him is as an involuntary committed man, MacMurphy, unlike most of the other men in the hospital, who are voluntarily in the hospital, MacMurphy can be held as long as the hospital officials desire.

MacMurphy and Ratchett are at odds throughout this movie. This film shows the down-side of this country'r mental health system where under-paid and overly officious health workers like Ratchett can use their power to abuse those supposedly in their care. This is shown best in Ratchett's treatment of teenager Billy (Brad Dourff) whom Ratchett controls by threatening to tell his mother of Billy's encounter with a woman MacMurphy brings into the hospital, at night, for a party. Billy is terrified that his mother will find out that he was with a woman, and Ratchett knows this, but nevertheless makes the threat to him.

There are vociferous critics int the United States of the psychiatric profession and of the use of medication to control the freedom of mental patients, the Church of Scientology being the most prominent. I don't agree with the critics' point of view, but this movie, in which several people are hurt in the oppressive mental hospital strengthens the case of those who dislike the mental health system in this country. This movie does a great job of showing MacMurphy's fight against oppression, to remain an individual in a totalitarian system, so I grade this film as earning 9 points out of 10. This film is deservedly among the top 100 ever according to the AFI and I encourage everyone, especially Jack Nicholson fans to watch it if they get the chance.

title: A Nicholson tour de force
review:
Every great once in a while there comes along an acting performance which elevates a very good movie and turns it into something very special. Jack Nicholson gives just such a performance in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. He is so good, so perfect in every way, that you are willing to overlook any minor quibbles you may have with the film and simply appreciate the magic and majesty of his performance. This is certainly not a perfect film by any means but the story is so powerful that it almost couldn't help but be a success no matter who was in the lead role. Placing the manic, irrepressible Nicholson center stage takes what always would have been at worst simply a good movie and makes it into something truly memorable.

Set in bleak 1960s Oregon, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest follows Randle Patrick McMurphy, as played by Nicholson, a troublemaking prisoner sent to a mental institution even though he is rather clearly not insane. At the very least when compared to the men who will become his fellow patients on the ward McMurphy is clearly the most sane, the most "normal" of the bunch. The men he encounters have been beaten down by the system. They've had the individuality, in fact their very lives, sucked out of them by the oppressive atmosphere in the institution. To these men, McMurphy will be something of a savior as he tries to show them there can still be more to life than their dreary day-to-day routine, some hope and joy even behind and hopefully one day beyond the institution's walls. Where McMurphy with his boundless energy, sharp wit and zest for life attempts to bring life into the ward he meets his match in the cold, domineering Nurse Ratched, played with perfect icy detachment by Louise Fletcher. Nurse Ratched very much likes having the men of the ward firmly under her thumb and will not react kindly to having her methods and authority questioned by the brash newcomer in the group. The conflict between McMurphy and Ratched is quite clear. They are fighting a battle for the minds, the very lives, of all the men on the ward. Both Nicholson and Fletcher fall into their roles perfectly. No accident both walked away with Oscars.

Where Nicholson and Fletcher are clearly the key figures here the rest of the cast is spot-on as well. Each of the patients on the ward is quite unique and all of the actors involved do a terrific job of bringing these characters to life. Notable in what were very early performances in their careers are some soon-to-be familiar faces, Danny DeVito and Christopher Lloyd. Brad Dourif as stuttering Billy, Will Sampson as silent Chief...the list of quality performances is staggeringly impressive. These fine actors bring this tremendous story to life. There are some moments which may seem a little out of place, perhaps a little forced. And there are times where things move a little more slowly than one might like. But whenever the movie threatens to really begin to drag there is a burst of Nicholson energy to propel it forward. Enjoyable and thought-provoking, in the end the film manages to be both uplifting and heartbreaking all at once. From the screenwriters to the director, the cinematographer and the wonderful cast it's a brilliant job all around.

title: Nod bad, interesting but maybe a bit overrated
review:
Well I enjoyed this film, its interesting and wasn't boring. But it doesn't have the depths I mean nothing to think about later, Nicholson is great and so in nurse witched, just doing their jobs, I didn't see wickensy or evil in the nurse she just did her duty. Nicholson is an actor you can't dislike, he brings life into that poor environment, but maybe he should have been more 'bad'.

This isn't a perfect movie, the chief 'suddenly' begins to respond, its too easy to escape from this place, the fishing scene might be unnecessary and unrealistic, maybe was shot due to the nice views, but there are many nice scenes. Maybe time also reduces the hype over the movie. I missed some love scene between Rutched and Jack.

Not bad but not so great.

title: One of the best movies Ever made.
review:
This is truly one of the best films ever made. While watching this movie it never feels like you are watching actors. It's very natural and subtle.

The first portion of the movie is hilarious with excellent performances of Jack Nicholson, Christopher Lloyd, Danny Devito, William Redfield, Brad Dourif and Louise Fletcher. You really get involved with the characters and will love them. This part is followed by some of the most heartbreaking scenes ever. Which will give you goosebumps every time you watch it again. This movie is without a doubt very much recommended.

title: One of the best movies ever made. A true masterpiece.
review:
"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" has won the Grand Slam of in the Academy Awards of 1975 (Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Screenplay) against stiff opposition and this is not for nothing. This movie, directed by Milos Forman, is a true masterpiece of human emotion and its themes of individual liberty creativity are universal and far-stretching. Although this movie is about a mental hospital, its themes are applicable to everything in our daily lives. R.P. McMurphy, superbly portrayed by Jack Nicholson (definitely his best role) who "fights and *ucks too much" is classified as mentally instable and sent to a mental asylum, exactly in the ward of Ms Ratched. Ratched is a control-freak and very old-fashioned, but she truly believes that she is helping her patients to get better. She is not Evil with a capital "E" and this one of the themes of the movie: How human beings can do harm to others without even knowing, actually thinking they're doing the right thing. McMurphy, fond of his personal freedom and creativity instills a sense of liberty and rebellion into his fellow ward companions, whose character is entirely imprisoned by the Ratched's engulfing persona. He gives them a confidence boost in their own abilities and tells them (in most cases rightly so) that they're not "crazier than the average man in the street". We get to know that the patients are staying willingly at the hospital and if they want they can quit. McMurphy is shocked when learning this, and so is the audience viewing the film. We ask ourselves - "why are they staying here, caged?". McMurphy tries to make his new friends liberate themselves and pursue a new active life. He is willing to risk his own freedom in order to achieve this goal - and in the end, he pays hard for it, although his aim is achieved. At the end of the movie, we have mixed feelings and strong emotions - we can both cry and cheer.

The acting and direction are top-notch, and the music at the end gives the ending an edge you'll find hard to forget. "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was based on a book of the same name, written by Ken Kesey. Find it and read it. And for God's sake, buy this movie, see it and cherish it for all your life.

10/10 - I just wish more movies like "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" were made.

title: Great
review: Absolutely Amazing. My favourite film ever. For one film to have so any career best performances by everyone who is in it, it shows the greatness of the picture. Jack puts his spin on the James Dean type character, and does it better than Jimmy. The film puts you through every emotion. From an amazing novel develops an even better movie. The film accepts the viewer into its wacky bunch of comic-book characters and you become friends with them instantly. Amazing Direction and Photography. Many laugh out loud moments as well as emotional ones, this resulting in a personally epic emotional roller-coaster movie. Must see for anyone.

title: Absolutely perfect in every possible way
review:
Please ignore any negative commentary on this movie, as it call comes from the know-it-all dissenters that are against all things good and all things "conformist." Allow them to conform with their fellow "nonconformists"

The movie is terribly perfect.

Acting and characters are awesome. Nicholson truly at his best, no question there. And Fletcher plays her role flawlessly. She's supposed to be a boring, impassive nurse -- duh! The supporting cast is just as deserving of kudos.

Based on a GREAT and classic book, probably one of the few movies that does any justice, along with To Kill A Mockingbird and the Grapes of Wrath.

This movies combines humor with poignancy and emotion. Great dialogue, great script, wonderful direction. Really, you can't complain at all.

10/10 - Far and away the best movie I own

title: Definitive Nicholson, Definitive Forman, Definitive '70s.
review:
"The 'cuckoo's nest' described by Forman is our very own nest. It's the world we poor lunatics live in, subjected to the bureaucratic rule of one set of oppressors and the economic pressure of another; forever chasing the promise of happiness, which here appears in the guise of liberty  but always obliged to swallow Miss Ratched's bitter little pills."

- Le Monde

Milos Forman's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" (1975) is arguably the most poignant cinematic social satire ever released through Hollywood  a tragic drama with streaks of bittersweet comedy lined throughout. The film uses a remote mental institute as a metaphor for society, and its odd inhabitants are likewise supposed to represent those of us who allow ourselves to be pacified by the bureaucratic oppressors. If we all rebelled like Randle P. McMurphy, would the world be a different place? And every time a free spirit like Randle is tamed, do we lose a fragment of our own freedom?

Released during a time when the nation's stability was a prescient issue and Americans were confused by their own surroundings, Forman manages to channel a built-up rage that he releases through the Jack Nicholson character. "Well I tried, didn't I? At least I did that," Randle (Nicholson) tells his fellow inmates of the hospital after attempting to lift a heavy water outlet from the ground. He struggles, but is unable to lift the massive slab of cement, and faces the stark realization of failure, perhaps for the first time in his life.

Randle has been sent to the mental rehabilitation center after being convicted of statutory rape of a minor, and assault. His plead is insanity, but the employees of the establishment are convinced that he is faking this illness in order to avoid being sent to jail.

Randle arrives for a six-week visit at the institute dressed in the clothes of a grimy everyman, complete with a beanie cap and a smug grin on his face that reeks of self-confidence. Randle soon finds that life at the institute is not as pleasant as he assumed it might be  Nurse Mildred Ratched (Louise Fletcher) takes an immediate dislike to Randle's rebellious nature, as he continually sparks uprisings amongst the crowd of typically indifferent patients, most of whom are startled by Randle's fearless attitude. He leads his troops into battle against Nurse Ratched, challenging the triviality of daily events, questioning everyday schedules and programs, escaping to go on boat trips, and throwing wild parties in the middle of the night.

Randle, through his irreverent approach to life, befriends Chief Bromden (Will Sampson), who is described early on as "dead and dumb." Of course, he isn't, and Randle's relationship with "Chief" eventually defines the essence of the film. By the finale, we realize that the story is really being told through Chief's perspective, and Randle is the link to the rest of the story.

Other inhabitants of the institute include the up-tight and eccentric Harding (William Redfield), the stuttering Billy Bibbitt (Brad Dourif), the innocently child-like Martini (Danny DeVito), and Taber (Christopher Lloyd), all of whom find themselves strangely drawn to the infectious wild nature of McMurphy, who opens their eyes to the joy of life, and in the defining moment of the film, explains that they've been convinced they're crazy, and are no less ordinary than the wackos who roam the streets outside their nest. The film is not a critique of modern psychiatric treatment. Instead, Forman aims higher at a monumental allegory about society, and in doing so creates a masterpiece of comedy and drama.

Forman, a Czech director infamous for his satirical sense of humor, lends a simplicity to the story that gives it a sharper edge; instead of using artsy camera shots or influential effects, Forman (who has gained a reputable career over the years and is responsible for a number of motion picture masterpieces) lets the camera take on the perspective of another patient in the hospital. We attend the daily seminars, escape for a boat trip, have an all-night party and get caught by the bitter Nurse Ratched, who witnesses the suicide of a patient towards the end of the movie and immediately insists that everyone continue on with their daily routines. McMurphy is outraged by her ignorance and schedules, and his proceeding actions eventually seal his own fate.

The film owes most of its success to Nicholson, whose career-defining performance has never been surpassed ever since  he isn't just playing McMurphy, he is McMurphy. With the beanie cap and the faded jeans and the general cynical edge of a man abandoned by society, Nicholson portrays McMurphy flawlessly. He was one of the big screen's first anti-heroes (followed a year later by the equally iconic Travis Bickle), and still remains a priceless capture of a time and age in America's past when its citizens  feeling betrayed by the Vietnam War  had no place to turn to, and in the end, slipped into a daze of self-destruction.

The movie took home all five primary Oscars in '75, making it the first film since "It Happened One Night" (1934) to have a clean sweep of Best Director, Best Actress, Best Director, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Picture. Needless to say, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" deserved them all, and is still an amazing motion picture masterpiece, even 29 years later.

title: A must-see for everyone
review:
***SPOILERS***

This is one of those movies that I always will remember. The script is based on the great book by Ken Kesey but I think that this movie is even better.

Jack Nicholson's character Patrick McMurphy has been transfered from a prison to a mental institution. This is not only a great drama but also a masterful satire of the way mentally challenged sometimes get treated at the mental hospitals. It's impossible not to like Jack Nicholsons character just as much as it's an impossibility not to hate Jessica Fletcher's role as nurse Ratched. She is superb as one of the meanest b*tches in film history. This movie is full of loveable and memorable characters such as Danny de Vito's Martini, Brad Dourif's Billy Bibbit and of course Will Sampson's chief one of the coolest guy's caught on tape. If you're 6' 7" and don't say word for over an hour in a movie then you deserve creds as hell.

This movie makes me both happy and sad, and for all you people who rate "The shawshank redemption" as the best movie you've seen, watch this and be amazed.

I have nothing more to say now than: watch, watch, watch!

title: How can a movie be so complete?
review:
For a long time I was so eager to see this movie, and one evening I couldn't wait anymore. Me and a good friend went in to the city and rented "One flew over the cuckoo's nest".

After watching the two hours and 9 minutes long movie, I was really so impressed, that I couldn't wait to see it again, so some weeks later I bought it on DVD. After watching it a couple of times, it made me realize how spectacular it actually is. I don't think I've seen such a complete movie, it almost got everything a movie can content. I don't think there's a single thing that could have been different, for making this movie better. The set, the characters and the story is all so magnificent, so near perfect.

"One flew over the cuckoo's nest" is one of my top 3 favorite movies, just as Jack Nicholson and Milos Forman goes on my list to, for being some of the greatest men in entertaining ever. All the Oscar's this movie was given, they're symbols of how perfect this movie is. I will say, that this is probably on the top 5 movies of all time, so it gets my full credit.

10/10

title: One of the few movies I consider the best.
review: This movie is extremely realistic. It demonstrated that an honest individual who is funny, who defends himself, who enjoys life, who is always himself is often punished and destroyed by other people... It's only one the strongest impression about this great movie among others I have. This is neither comedy nor tragedy but is a tragicomedy which makes it even more realistic since our life is just that... Another strongest idea: good intentions in fact are horrible, they may lead to deadly consequences like we saw in this masterpiece...

title: Essential Jack
review:
Milos Forman's immortal "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is the stunning story of Randle P. McMurphy, a convict who feigns insanity to escape the work farm. Full of mischievous vitality, McMurphy becomes a hero to his fellow mental patients and a bane to the institution's administration, particularly one Nurse Ratched.

The film is a brilliant portrayal of tragedy and redemption. Jack Nicholson's performance as McMurphy is simply one of the best that he - or any other actor- has ever delivered. Louise Fletcher's work as the controlling, vicious Nurse Ratched is unforgettable, as is Will Sampson's turn as the stoic Chief.

title: Brilliant and Incredibly depressing film
review:
***MINOR SPOILERS***

This is, without a doubt, a brilliant film. It was well scripted, well acted, well directed, and there are few, if any, flaws. The only problem I have with this film is how depressing it is. I was shell shocked after I had watched it. I didn't know what to think. The first part of the movie was a comedy through and through. I watched it the entire time with almost an air of smugness. The first part was nothing compared to the second though. The end is what makes this a brilliant and thought provoking film. My smugness disappeared in the last twenty minutes. Though the ending is ultimately uplifting with the fate of Chief, the events surrounding it are horrifying and depressing. I wholeheartedly recommend this movie, but I also recommend that you prepare yourself for something other than a comedy.

PS. Does anyone know why Louise Fletcher won best actress? She was just not that good.

title: not a simple movie
review: i think that this movie is not as simple and easy to understand as it appears for the first time.and also it's not a comedy (or maybe black comedy).i think the director wanted to tell us lots of things and to send messages to us (not only a story about some mental patients in a hosp.and the brilliant thing (beside the genius Nicholson)is the director made his movie so that any level of audience can understand it easily.

title: Great Movie, but a comedy???
review:
This is a very moving picture about the emasculation of modern man. I was reviewing the top rated movies in different categories and saw this movie as the top rated "comedy." Comedy is defined as follows: Main Entry: com·e·dy Pronunciation: 'kä-m&-dE Function: noun Inflected Form(s): plural -dies Etymology: Middle English, from Middle French comedie, from Latin comoedia, from Greek kOmOidia, from kOmos revel + aeidein to sing -- more at ODE Date: 14th century 1 a : a medieval narrative that ends happily Dante's Divine Comedy b : a literary work written in a comic style or treating a comic theme 2 a : a drama of light and amusing character and typically with a happy ending b : the genre of dramatic literature dealing with the comic or with the serious in a light or satirical manner -- compare TRAGEDY 3 : a ludicrous or farcical event or series of events 4 a : the comic element the comedy of many life situations b : humorous entertainment nightclub comedy

This movie is not a comedy. It needs to be removed from this list. There is such thing as a "comedy drama," e.g. Pretty Woman, but I don't think this movie has enough laughs in it to make that category. Even though Hamlet has comic relief, that doesn't make it a comedy drama.

title: Brilliant in every aspect
review: This film, based on Ken Kersey's novel which I haven't read, was simply spectacular. It had a very unique blend of comedy, drama, horror (of the worst kind), and tragedy. Jack Nicholson conveyed the complexities of his character so perfectly, it's hard to adequately praise him. Louise Fletcher's Nurse Ratched, the ultimate authoritarian conformist, was the perfect foil for Nicholson's free-spirited and idealistic McMurphy. The supporting cast had actors who would go on to become big names like Danny Devito, Christopher Lloyd, and Vincent Schiavelli (Tomorrow Never Dies). One of the best films I've ever seen, 10/10.

title: Just saw it again on DVD, a classic!
review: I saw "Cuckoo" many years ago, probably in the theater. It is strange how we remember certain things vividly, but others not at all. Nurse Ratched is truly a demon, you get to feeling all the inmates should be free, if just to get away from her. In a sense she is worse than the warden in "Shawshank Redemption". She kills not with guns, but with emotional torture. Nicholson's performance is inspired but the ending is depressing and uplifting at the same time. It will never be remembered as one of my favorites, but I will always remember "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest."

title: Wow.
review:
McMurphy is a convict who feigned mental illness to get out of working in prison. Upon arriving, though, he finds that life in the mental ward is not all it's cracked up to be. The staff seems to care little about the patients, perhaps even resenting them. He comes into conflict with the big nurse, who is intent on controlling the patients like puppets. McMurphy takes it upon himself to alleviate the situation.

This is a great movie, but it was very different from the book. Chief Bromden was originally the main character throughout the entire book, while in the movie, he only becomes the primary character near the end. The book was also filled with Bromden's bizarre hallucinations, which don't seem to come into play here.

Nevertheless, Jack Nicholson was totally rad as McMurphy. This is definetly one worth owning.

title: Where do you suppose she lives?
review: SPOILER WARNING!! Is "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" the greatest film of all time?  Perhaps not, but it is certainly one of the greatest.  And, in both Jack's and Louise's performances, it contains some of the finest screen acting you will ever, EVER, see.  Maybe you prefer to watch computer-generated dolts hitting each other in slow-motion.  I wish you all the luck in the world. Meanwhile, Jack is arriving at the mental institution, in the cold and gloom.  That weird music is playing.  The Chief, Nurse Ratched, Danny Devito, Chris Lloyd, Brad Dourif and all the rest of the guys are waiting for him to turn their lives upside down.  Here he comes now, with his cap, his leather jacket (notice how the colour scheme of his clothes slowly changes throughout the film until he's clad in all-white, just like the rest of them), his crazy grin, his rapid-fire chatter, his profanity, his spirit. The sad-sack inmates need him and fear him in roughly equal measure.  Their world is ordered and petty and routine, dominated by the terrifying Nurse (Louise Fletcher - what an astonishingly controlled performance she gives). MacMurphy is the last thing they need.  Playing basketball and going fishing ("Dr. Scanlon - the famous Dr. Scanlon") and watching the ball game (or not) and drinking and - hell - living, are not on the agenda.  The authorities cannot control someone like Mac ("I fight and **** too much"), they cannot even understand him.  Think of those great scenes in which men in suits ask him sensible questions and he responds by displaying a pornographic playing card and asking, "where do you suppose she lives?".  Think also of how awesomely easy it is to escape, and how he never manages it.  Why?  Why doesn't he go out the window that night?  Why doesn't he just disappear when they go for the fishing trip?  These are the questions that keep you awake at night.  "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" lingers long in the mind.  Its haunting imagery, brilliant dialogue and wonderful ending remind you of the true power of the movies.

title: The greatest Movie Metaphor of all time
review: Who among us is not in their own "insane asylum"? What keeps us from achieving all that we wish? Why are we afraid to free our spirit? Why do we live vicariously or anethetize ourselves. In this stunning movie, JP McMurphy is committed to a mental ward. When he discovers that his fellow inmates are there voluntarily,he is dumbfounded. MacMurphy makes them laugh and he makes them begin to think, much to nurse ratchid's dismay. They hold him up as a god, and for the first time they begin to take small steps toward independence. They eventually drain MacMurphy of his spirit but not before one of his disciples decides to overcome his fear and take action in one of the most breathtaking endings in movie history.

title: One Would Be Cuckoo NOT To Like This Movie
review:
I was rather disappointed in my Junior year in high school when I found out we weren't going to be reading the book. I heard that the book and movie were brilliant. Finally, I got a hold of this movie, and all that I heard didn't do this fantastic movie justice.

Jack Nicholson is probably one of the greatest actors I have ever seen. Then there were a few other surprises in the cast. I didn't know that Danny DeVito and Christopher Lloyd were in this movie, but they did great too.

The nurse was great. One of those characters you love to hate, much like the antagonist in the Patriot. The characters in this movie were very diverse and realistic, as many people DO have these problems.

Other things were addressed in this movie that I cannot mention as they would spoil it for those who haven't seen it. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a long movie, but it isn't boring. It also has something for everybody. Don't take my word for it, go see it yourself. 10/10.

title: Nicholson's greatest role
review: This film stands above so many films of the 70s.  It really scores high for realistic acting.  Nicholson's performance is absolute gold.  The film also mixes humour and drama extremely well, one minute we're laughing only then to descend into sadness. Powerful.  The film also has respect for its characters, although not to the point of becoming sappy and being afraid to use them for comic effect when appropriate.  Nicholson isn't the only actor to watch out for - everyone is on form, there's not a weak performance in the whole picture.  Each character is crafted and endearing (or realistically menacing in the case of Louise Fletcher).  Special note must be made of Sydney Lassick as Cheswick, a nice little character and a fine portrayal.  The film is extremely quotable and full of memorable scenes.

title: the best american movie ever
review: This is the best performance of Nicholson,and of DeVito too.It's hard to say that the people in the hospital are acting,they are so real looking. I think it's the ultimate presentation of mentally ill individuals that you can see on a movie. A REAL,unforgettable chef-d'oeuvre!

title: Best Movie Of It's Time
review: This probably the best movie that Jack Nicholson ever did. His performance outranks anything he has ever done. As Randle P. MacMurphy, he is a convict that just doesn't get along. It is decided to have him checked out at a mental hospital, which to him is a big joyride. He meets some patients there, and soon has them doing things for themselves. He is especially fond of the Chief, played by Will Sampson. The chief has the staff at the hospital beleiving that he is deaf and dumb, and he is neither. MacMurphy is the only one that knows this. He also develops a true hatred for Nurse Ratched (played by Louise Fletcher). MacMurphy shows his dislike for her by constantly breaking the rules. He takes the patients on a bus ride, and then on a fishing trip. He also brings in some women and booze to have a party on the ward. He was already givin shock treatments for interfering in a fight on the ward, and after Nurse Ratched causes Billy to commit suicide, MacMurphy really loses it, and tries to choke Nurse Ratched. It is decided that MacMurphy is dangerous, and he is givin a lobotomy. The Chief, after seeing his friend a vegetable, decides that he does not want the other patients to see him in that condition, and smothers MacMurphy. After this, the Chief escapes from the hospital using the water cooler to break the window. This is in homage to MacMurphy, and is very moving. Again, I say this is the best movie of it's time.

title: This movie is awesome!
review:
I knew absolutely nothing about this movie when I rented it, other than the fact that it was about a mental institution. The film is in many ways like the later PATCH ADAMS, following one man's journey after he is sent to a hospital for the insane and learns that by helping others, he is also helping himself.

When the film ended, I was shocked to find that Louise Fletcher (HIGH SCHOOL HIGH), Christopher Lloyd (PREMONITION), Scatman Crothers (THE SHINING), and Danny DeVito (DEATH TO SMOOCHY) were also members of the cast. I had no idea they were in the film until it ended.

I call this film a personal favorite of mine, and I recommend it to anyone who enjoyed PATCH ADAMS. I know I did, and actually, I think ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST is a lot better. Jack Nicholson did a great job. See this movie! ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST gets 5/5.

title: good
review: This is a good movie, but like most other movies on here, it's pretty overrated. I still liked it enough to buy it though. I think the movie is more comedic than it is dramatic. I like this whole movie except for the end, which i won't ruin. bye.

title: There's a thin line between sanity and insanity and he crossed the line
review: Jack Nicholson uses his talents for manic characters well in this movie. Louise Fletcher is stone cold and evil and an equal match for Nicholson. The whole movie from start to finish makes you wonder how you would react to such a situation.  I like the twists and the turns in the movie especially one the with Indian chief.  Christopher Lloyd, Danny DeVito and others round out this great ensemble movie about life in the mental ward. Cucukoo's Nest sets a standard for how mental institutions should NOT be run. Nicholson as R.P, McMurphy portrays one of the most memorable characters from literature. A must see movie.

title: POWERFUL
review:
This movie is my all time favorite movie. The script,acting,and directing are all superb.

The movie is about Jack Nicholson(in his best performance) going into a mental hospital and trying to get the patients to exert themselves and how Louise Fletcher( brilliant as the head nurse) tries to stop him.

Funny,dramatic,touching,and sad all at the same time. All around it's a superb movie. 10/10

title: Forman+Nicholson=Superb
review:
This is a very special film,it`s the first of it`s kind and it had to be Milos Forman(man on the moon, amadeus)that directed it,it was his breaktrough and it put him on the list of the other great directors, Scorsese,Stone,Coppolla and Tarantino.

The acting in this film is so great that everybody that acted in this movie deserved an Academy Award. Jack Nicholson got one for his role as McMurphy, and Louise Fletcher also got one for her role as nurse Ratched.The story is very fascinating and actually very touching.It is a very funny film to,it`s a bit like Man on the moon.You don`t know if you should cry or laugh.

This is maybe the greatest film ever made and it is a must-see for everybody that likes to watch a good film.Milos Forman`s directing is so good it`s almost scary(he also got an Oscar for Best Director). Jack Nicholson(as usual)is more than great,he`s fantastic in his role,so don`t miss out on this one. It is one of the greatest.

title: mmmm...Yummy
review: I saw this film recently...and what superb excellence. I am convinced now that Jack Nicholson (next to Dustin Hoffman) is the finest actor pulled out of America ever. He remarkably adopts the role of Randal.P. McMurphy ( a con who had the idea that spending time in a mental institution would be easier that fufilling his custodial sentence) The Irony is that McMurphy started off sane when he entered the institution and ended up being labotomised If you use you eyes you spot other famous thespians in that film like Louise Fletcher as the soft spoken but cruel Nurse Ratchit, Danny Devito, Brad Dourif and Christopher Lloyd also make noticable appearances as some of the inmates. This film is funny, touching and in some places disturbing but it is without a doubt one of cinema's greatest moments when it was released in 1975.

title: Did you know...
review: This film remains Jacks best work of art (As good as it gets included), Foreman done a great job too, but with such an outstanding cast, it was impossible for him to do anything less. Although i am not taking anything away from him. I have recently read that it was actually filmed in a state mental institution, and that Jack turned up there two weeks before it began shooting and actually mingled amongst the inmates. He ate with them and actually sat in on a couple of electric shock treatments, the kind of which he endured in the film...(Robert De Nero eat your heart out) and did you know that the head psychiatrist was the actual head psychiatrist in the institution... as were the rest of the inmates. One flew over the cuckoos nest in my opinion was and will always be the best movie ever made...it just goes to show that not every film needs to be high concept... to be a high success.

title: Undeniable Classic
review:
I can't think of any movie that has characters written so well, or emotions so brilliantly felt and delivered as much as this one.

Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher were astounding, and the script was incredible! This film makes the audience root for a very unique and three-dimensional protagonist. The movie never finds a slow point, and the director ignites this amazing story of a group of "crazy" people who change their lives.

This is not your average feel-good movie. I give it a 10!

title: The second best movie of 1975
review:
Cuckoo's Nest is a great film, there is no doubt about that. But unfortunately this film swept everything that year at the Oscars and Jaws was left out in the cold. Now Jaws is the film that I consider to be the best film ever made and because of it I used to have a personal chip on my shoulder about Cuckoo's Nest. I could never understand why a film like this one was so much more heralded than Jaws. But now that I am little older I can appreciate the fact that the Academy is really quite political and there was no way that a 27 year old director was going to beat out Milos Forman for best picture and best director. But that aside, I have to admit that ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST is one fantastic film. I just had to get that out of the way first.

Jack gives, what I think, is his best performance ever in film. Here he a driven, tenacious and determined man. I can only think of two other characters in film that exhibit qualities like Randal McMurphy, and those are Rambo and Indy. But seeing as McMurphy is more real and more believable, that honour has to go to him. Cuckoo's Nest is an inspirational film and if there is one line that will always be remembered in this film, it is the line, " Well at least I tried, ***dammit!" That is the epitome of what the film and the character are all about. Sure there is the underlying theme of the common man against evil society but I like it better to think of it just as a film about one mans struggle to rise to the occassion and conquer some very stacked odds.

What is also great about the film is to see some actors early in their career. Brad Dourif, Danny Devito and Christopher Lloyd all have roles in the film and they have all gone on to have extensive careers in the Game.

There really isn't much more I can add to what Cuckoo's Nest is all about, I'm sure you have seen and read it all before. All I can say is that is an inspirational movie about not giving up and standing up for what you believe is right. And it is done extremely well. It is not as good as Jaws ( nothing is ) but that is not a fault of it's own. Milos Forman is no Steven Spielberg but that is another story and this film...... ah hell, why don't we just leave it at that. It's a great film and Jack is at his best. That's all you really need to know.

9 out of 10

title: My all time favorite...
review: This movie is just incredible.  It leaves me motionless from beginning to end, and I can't say that about most films.  Totally encompassing as the drama of the situation plays out in front of you.  Forman's best work as a director, and equalled by the script and cast.

title: Simply my favorite movie of all time
review:
This is my favorite movie of all time. I'm not saying it is the greatest ever made- there are many more titles that could easily vie for that title. This movie isn't really a film in the sense that there isn't a particularly memorable piece of camera work or composition. However, director Forman knows what to do: he gets out of the way and lets his actors tell the captivating story of the individual courageously fighting for identity against "the machine".

Cuckoo's Nest is an actor's movie. The ensemble work here by Nicholson, Fletcher, Lloyd, Redfield, Lasker,Sampson, Devito and the rest is amoung the finest ever captured. I can not find a false note in any of the performances. These actors fully inhabit the skins of these characters and therefore, create three dimensional people.

The script is air tight as it oscillates between comedy and tragedy often not only in the same scene but in the same take. I know Kesey has disowned this film and I don't blame him considering the experience he had, however the film compliments his novel nicely. Many of my favorite lines in film history are in this movie. "Least I tried, G*******t, least I did that!" is a motto that has guided my life.

When viewed with its near twin Cool Hand Luke (my third favorite film of all time), one can see the possibly dated, but no less intriguing subtext of the criminal/prisoner as savior. Many souls are saved as a direct result of McMurphy's (and Luke's) ultimate sacrifice.

The film is entertaining, enlightening and reflective without the ever so slightest hint of pretension.

With each viewing (I've seen the film probably 30+ times) it appears as fresh and beautiful as the first. A definate 10 out of 10.

title: Powerful, indeed!
review: I first saw this movie with my father when I was 13. Not being subjected to all that many 'R' movies, I was excited. Even though I was only at the young age of 13, I absorbed the movie with full understanding. This is probably the best movie Jack Nicholson has ever been in, and is POWERFUL POWERFUL POWERFUL! And if you agree with this while viewing Cuckoo's Nest, just wait until the ending.

title: This may be the best movie of the decade.
review: This may be the best movie of the decade.  No film matches it in the strength of the performances or emotional impact.  Seeing the conditions of the mental institutions of the day are shockingly portrayed, and it is a testament to the medical society at large, that they have brought back the use of electric shock therapy.

title: Great film!!!!
review: I love this film!  The performances were great, with strong performances by Louise Fletcher, Jack Nicholson, and all of the inmates.  I really liked how the sequence of events all led up to the startling conclusion. <<SPOILER WARNING>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>When I first became acquainted with this film by reading a 15-page summary of it on Mr. Hollywood or some other film site like that, I cried when I read about Randall's lobotomy.  I was really troubled that someone with so much vigor and passion was turned into a passive vegetable by the establishment. Not only that, but the reactions of the patients in my mind as I read horrified me.  As far as the Chief's murder of Randall is concerned, I am against euthanasia actively and it bothered me very much but I respect that it was put into the film and novel.  The Chief saw it as something that had to be done before he made his escape. <<<<<<<<<<<<<END SPOILER WARNING>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Anyways, I really enjoyed this film and all the performances elicited strong emotions.  It deserved all the Oscars it received.

title: The man who...
review:
When one of us interns at boarding school saw this when I was a kid and told us about it, he couldn't remember Nicholson's name in the film, so long-windedly described him as 'the man who wields all the powers' which is accurate but my god, it made an already protracted film seem endless. None of us did the obvious thing and say to him, "look, just call him NICHOLSON." That proves conclusively that Brad Doruff is no crazier than the average arsehole walking the streets.

Kirk Douglas wanted to make and star in this film originally because he saw 'the man who wields all the powers' as a Christ figure. This is a popular sentiment among many that is inexplicable and silly to me. Christ believed one should help others without thinking of a reward. 'The man who wields all the powers' thought only of himself and what he could con out of the system. He stimulated the people around him but that doesn't make him a saint as it was accidental, not by design. He didn't give a damn that when he stole the fishing boat, any one of the patients could have got seriously hurt or gone overboard and got lost at sea.

This film meanders on too long and the last quarter is nasty stuff. 'The man who wields all the powers' doesn't give a damn once again that mentally incapable people may drown on their own vomit after getting them plastered on booze. Are we meant to find it funny that drink was funneled down their throats? A Christ figure? People are so deluded.

The portrayal of psychiatric staff was also unfair, representing 'the state' and conformism over the susposedly admirable individuality and freedom (to exploit others) of 'the man who wields all the powers.' I think they did the best job they could with the perceived psychiatric wisdom of the day and is order so bad when you consider the reckless endangerment of others by the 'man who wields all the powers?' Nurse Ratched's tragic threat to Billy was ill considered, even reprensible but does that make her the monster she was portrayed? We are all human and anyone can lose their temper when confronted with the endangerment of patients and the destruction of property which she would be held accountable for and her staff would have to take long hours clearing up. Obviously, one has to accept the picture in the liberal, counter-culture context of the times but although it was well acted, it was neither a great or distinguished piece of film making.

title: Kesey lite
review: I love this movie.  It is direct, powerful, funny and sad and uplifting, and, I think, perfectly proportioned.  Nevertheless, I can understand why Kesey allegedly won't watch the movie.  The man imagined the whole story and wrote the book, and he told the story the way he believed it should be told. In his tale, a shock-shopworn lunatic lives with McMurphy in the hospital and, through his influence, learns the meaning of freedom.  Or something like that.  Kesey's novel is written in first-person by the lunatic, Chief Bromden - the deaf, dumb, crazy Indian.  In the book, Bromden is observant, imaginative, smart, and at least a little daffy, especially in the first half.  Readers enjoy the progress of Bromden toward functional sanity and appreciate more fully how McMurphy's example of "free living" affected the entire ward.  The movie works much better than it should, because it doesn't even try to capture the flavor of the book.  It retells the key events of Kesey's novel, as though the book were nothing but a plot with dialogue. Fortunately the plot is strong enough to survive simplification, compression, and pragmatic alterations (e.g. keeping a character who commits suicide midway through the book alive all through the film, apparently to keep the tragedies to a bare dramatic minimum).  The ending of the film, with Jack Nizsche's uplifting "Native American" theme, is a knockout.  If there is anyone who has neither seen this film nor read the book, I'd recommend seeing the film before plunging into the book.  That way, both can be enjoyed to the fullest extent.

title: Best film ever made about disabled people and institutions.
review: While Jack Nicholson, Brad Dourif, and Louise Fletcher take top honors for their portrayals in this film, as they should, the whole point of the film as an expression of outrage against how people are marginalized in our culture, was made by Christopher Lloyd's character.  Mr. Taber (Lloyd) drops a cigarette in his pants cuff unknowingly, and it sets the pants on fire. When he reacts to the burning and danger by jumping around and yelling, he is dragged off and tied down.  People who are handicapped or mentally ill cannot express anger or fear or desire or even pain, without it being seen as a threat.  The real handicaps here are the "normal" people in the "helping professions."  Best movie of all time.

title: Nicholson's all-time performance.
review:
Probably one of the hardest psychological movies ever if not THE hardest, Milos Forman's classic is still brilliant. Script, acting, and directing are flawless. Nicholson plays Randall P. McMurphy, a free-spirited man sent to the mental institute for statutory rape and other previous convictions.

The only difference between Randall and the other patients is that he is very lucid of what is going on in that institute and he is especially conscious of the fact that the evil head-nurse, nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher in her Oscar-winning performance) is there only to make sure that the crazy become crazier.

There are many great scenes in this gem (like the ending). However, if a drop of blood makes you faint, you'll never be able to watch this one. It's an excellent movie.

title: Without exception, the finest motion picture ever made.
review:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? Jack Nicholson's performance is a searing tour de force that I consider to be the finest movie performance of all time. Every supporting role is superb, most notably Louise Fletcher and a small but solid performance from Brad Dourif.

Milos Forman's direction has a sort of gritty, documentary-style texture to it that gives the film just that little extra effectiveness. The writing and dialog are perhaps the greatest in any film, with Nicholson delivering the film's most memorable lines (and there are many). Every single scene is incredible in its own right, from McMurphy's re-enactment of the World Series to a joy ride on a fishing boat. The final 30 minutes or so are absolutely staggering in their emotional intensity.

If you have not yet seen this film, stop reading now and literally run to your local video store to rent it. It is the most powerful, emotional, and involving movie ever put on film. See it, for it is without exception the finest motion picture ever made.

title: Classic movies are always good!
review: Every classic movie that I have seen that has won best picture and the ones that haven't, have always been good!  This one in particular is my favorite...and has easily became one of my favorite movies on my top 10, well maybe #1. First off I would just say that I also came into this movie about 2 years ago because Jack was in it...and he is my favorite actor...but after I finished the movie and was like 'WOW!'  Film making and acting at its best!!!  You can't top this as being one of the best classics...9 out of 10 !!!!

title: A Timeless Classic!
review:
This movie isn't one of my favorite movies of all time, but it is one of the GREATEST movies I ever seen in my life. It's powerful, funny, dramatic, and impressing. Jack Nicholson gives us a brilliant performance as the strange and hyper McMurphy, who just loves to have the attention focused on him and of course, in many ways, puts a smile on every one of the patients' faces.

Jack Nicholson is the ONLY actor who can really fit the bill as McMurphy and who could forget Louise Fletcher's moody and cold hearted character, Nurse Ratched, and the thought-to-be dumb and deaf patient, Big Chief. Every character in the movie is natural and has all different types of personalities, which makes them all very special and better yet, unforgettable.

I read the book by Ken Kesey, and in my opinion, the movies better! A must see for anyone who loves movies!!! :o)

title: The Greatest Film EVER Made
review:
People may say that Citizen Kane is number one or Casablanca or even newer films or animated ones. But Milos Foreman's One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is the best film EVER made. It is a tragic and hilarious. Touching and moving. It is both drama and comedy and balances it well.

Nicholson gives the performance of his career he deserved his award as did Fletcher. True this was Nicholson's film but he certainly was not my favorite character. That title belongs to the character of good ol' Charlie Cheswick. He was warm and moving and equally naive. Cheswick stole just about all of the scenes he was in.

This film usually has to suffer the debate of whether this or Jaws was better. Yes Jaws changed the summer blockbuster, was Steven Spielberg's masterpiece and is remembered more but the Academy Awards was 100% right in choosing this as the best picture of 1975. It is by far a superior picture. Not to say Jaws is bad but this film is the king of the motion picture industry.

The bottom line is this is my favorite film and will always be because of it's authenticity ( real mental institution patients were used) and it's tragicly funny story. In my opinion it is the definitive masterpiece, classic and number 1.

title: Great, classic film making...
review:
One Flew Over is an amazing book/movie combo in that both pieces interact somewhat, but stand on their own well. The book is amazing and well worth the read. The movie is different enough in point of view and events to make it stand on its own.

Nicholson is, as almost always, incredible in the McMurphy character. It's amazing that you can laugh at something in one scene ("Little dab'll do ya, huh?") and then see the results of this same character in the final scenes. The character of Chief is perfectly portrayed, and in fact every patient comes through with his or her character intact.
